sentences.sentence: It was not until the twenty-third year of my time on this island that I saw any human being come near the island.
My fear of being discovered and eaten by natives, however, put an end to all my previous invention.
I dared not to drive a nail( 钉钉子 ), much less to fire a gun, for fear the noise I might make should be heard.
I worried about my safety now more than my food.
I could have been content to have spent the rest of my time on the island, even to the last moment, until I died.
I had also found some little amusements( 娱乐活动 ), which made the time pass a great deal more pleasantly than it did before.
I had taught my Poll to speak, and he did it so familiarly, and talked quite well.
He lived with me no less than( 多达 ) twenty-six years.
How long he might have lived afterwards( 之后 ) I do not know, though I know they have an idea in the Brazils that parrots( 鹦鹉 ) live a hundred years.
My dog was a pleasant and loving companion to me for no less than sixteen years of my time, and then died of old age.
I began to be very well satisfied with the life I led, if I could have been free from the fear of the natives.
But it was otherwise planned.
Going out early in the morning in the month of December, I was surprised to see a fire upon the shore, at a distance of about two miles.
I was terribly surprised at the sight.
I did not dare to go out, but prepared myself within my cave, getting myself ready to defend.
I loaded all my guns, and decided to defend myself to the last breath.
I climbed to the top of a hill, where I presently found there were no fewer than nine naked( 裸体的 ) natives.
They were sitting round a small fire they had made, not to warm them, but to cook some of their horrible( 可怕的 ) diet of human flesh.
They had two boats with them, and they seemed to be waiting for the tide( 潮水 ) to come in to go away again.
As I expected, I soon saw them all take their boats and row away.
As soon as I saw they had gone, I took two guns upon my shoulders, and with all speed made for( 向...走去 ) the place I had seen them.
As soon as I got there, I could see the marks of horror( 惨状 ) which they had left behind.
There were the flesh, blood, and bones of the human bodies they had eaten.
I was so filled with anger at the sight, that I now began to plan the destruction of the next native that I saw there.
It was more than fifteen months before any more of them came on shore there again.
The disturbance( 忧虑 ) of my mind during these fifteen or sixteen months was very great.
I slept poorly, dreamed frightful dreams, and often woke up out of my sleep in the night.
In the day great troubles upset my mind, and in the night I dreamed often of killing the natives, and of the reasons why I might be justified in doing it.
But allow me to delay discussing this further for a while.
It was in the middle of May that a very great storm of wind blew all day, with a great deal of lightning and thunder.
As I was reading the Bible( 圣经 ), I was surprised by the noise of a gun, coming from the sea.
I rushed to the top of the hill, reaching it at the very moment that a flash of fire made me listen for a second gun.
It was from that part of the sea where I had been driven by the current in my boat.
I immediately considered that this must be some ship in danger.
I brought together all the dry wood I could get, and set it on fire upon the hill.
As soon as my fire had lit up, I heard another gun, and after that several others, all from the same location( 地点 ).
I worked my fire all night long till dawn( 黎明 ), when I saw something far out at sea.
As the weather grew clearer, I could plainly see the wreck( 残骸 ) of a ship.
In the situation I was in, I could only look upon the misery( 不幸 ) of the poor men, and pity them.
As the wind grew calmer, I thought about going out in my boat to this wreck( 残骸 ).
I did not doubt that I would find something on the ship that might be useful to me.
But more importantly, I thought there might still be some living creature on the ship, whose life I might save.
I rushed back to my cave, prepared everything for my voyage, and went down to my boat.
As I remembered the rapid currents which ran constantly on both sides of the island, my heart began to fail me, but I was determined to go.
As soon as I pushed out, the current carried me at a great rate.
Steering( 操纵 ) with my paddle( 浆 ), I went directly for the wreck( 残骸 ), and in less than two hours I came up to it.
It was a sad sight to see: the ship, which by the look of it was Spanish, was jammed tight( 紧紧地 ) in between two rocks, and badly beaten by the sea.
I went on board, but the first sight I met with was two men drowned( 淹死 ) in the cook-room, with their arms tight( 紧紧的 ) around one another.
There was no one left alive in the ship, nor many goods that were not spoiled( 损坏 ) by the water.
I found several guns in several boxes, and a container with about four pounds of gunpowder( 火药 ) in it.
I took these supplies and went away.
That same evening, about an hour into the night, I reached the island again.
Having now brought these things on shore and put them safely away, I began to calm myself, to live in my usual way, and to take care of my affairs.
I lived in this condition nearly two more years, but these two years I was filled with projects and designs of how I might get away from this island.
It was a night in the rainy season in March, the twenty-fourth year after my first setting foot on this lonely island, when I had a rather strange dream.
I dreamed that as I was going out in the morning, as usual, from my castle, I saw upon the shore two boats and eleven natives coming to land.
They brought with them another native, whom they were going to kill, in order to eat him.
Suddenly, the native that they were going to kill jumped away, and ran for his life. I thought in my sleep that he came running into my little tent, to hide himself.
I showed myself to him, and he kneeled( 跪下 ) down to me, and he became my servant.
As soon as I had got this man, I said to myself, “Now, I may certainly go to the mainland, for this fellow will serve me as a pilot.”
So great was my joy at the possibility of my escape, that I felt an unbearable disappointment upon waking to discover that it was only a dream.

article_info.previous: 昨天我们读到Robinson经过不懈努力，终于回到自己居住的小岛。他跪谢上帝并且放弃逃离小岛的念头。然而，几年的平静生活过后，Robinson在海滨发现了一个脚印。这使他惊恐不已，并开始为后面的生活做准备。
article_info.share_words: My fear of being discovered and eaten by natives, however, put an end to all my previous invention.

question.cn: 那些土著人在火上烤什么？
question.en: What did those natives cook on the fire?

analysis: 文中说：“They were sitting round a small fire they had made, not to warm them, but to cook some of their horrible diet of human flesh.”所以选B。

question.cn: 那些土著人在岛上待了很久吗？
question.en: Did those natives stay long on the island?

analysis: 文中说：“As I expected, I soon saw them all take their boats and row away. ”所以选B。

question.cn: 那些土著人走后，他感觉怎么样？
question.en: How was Robinson after those natives went away?

options.cn: 他很长一段时间都很害怕。
options.en: He was so frightened for a long time.

options.cn: 他有一点担心，但之后都睡得很好。
options.en: He was a little frightened but slept well ever after.

analysis: 文中说：“The disturbance of my mind during these fifteen or sixteen months was very great. I slept poorly, dreamed frightful dreams, and often woke up out of my sleep in the night.”所以选A。

question.cn: 在五月的一天，什么让Robinson那么吃惊？
question.en: What made Robinson so surprised on a day in May ?

analysis: 文中说： “I was surprised by the noise of a gun, coming from the sea.”所以选C。

question.cn: 西班牙船上有幸存者吗？
question.en: Were there any survivors left on the Spanish ship?

analysis: 文中说：“There was no one left alive in the ship, nor many goods that were not spoiled by the water.” 所以选B。

share_title: 100天读完4本英文书，今天是第57天
